caption.body: Annabelle Lopez Ochoa was selected as one of twelve choreographers to create a thirty-minute ballet for San Francisco Balletâ€™s ğ˜œğ˜¯ğ˜£ğ˜°ğ˜¶ğ˜¯ğ˜¥: ğ˜ˆ ğ˜ğ˜¦ğ˜´ğ˜µğ˜ªğ˜·ğ˜¢ğ˜­ ğ˜°ğ˜§ ğ˜•ğ˜¦ğ˜¸ ğ˜ğ˜°ğ˜³ğ˜¬ğ˜´ (2018). For her first San Francisco Ballet commission, ğ˜ğ˜¶ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¯ğ˜ªğ˜¤ğ˜¢, Lopez Ochoa drew inspiration from painter Pablo Picasso (1881â€“1973), particularly ğ˜ğ˜¶ğ˜¦ğ˜³ğ˜¯ğ˜ªğ˜¤ğ˜¢ (1937), which he painted in response to the devastating bombing of the Basque town Guernica during the Spanish Civil War.  In her choreography, Lopez Ochoa sought to answer the question â€œHow do you put cubism into movement?â€ She created cubist effects by arranging dancers into poses, so that the brain appears to see four heads and only two legs. The four principal dancers appear on stage as four embodiments of a person, sometimes separate, sometimes in pairs, or as a foursome.   Lopez Ochoaâ€™s ballet also encompasses flamenco dance and bullfighting. The four principal dancers wear bull horns; the bull symbolizes violence and powerâ€”aggressor and victim.  Special thank you to San Francisco Ballet for making this exhibition possible. See â€œSan Francisco Ballet at 90â€ on display, pre-security, in the International Terminal and online at: https://bit.ly/SFBalletAt90
